New Collection of Ancient Unusual SÅ«tras Recorded by An Shigao, Part 1
The New Collection of Ancient Unusual SÅ«tras Recorded by An Shigao, Part 1. Ancient unusual sÅ«tras are
the remaining texts from earlier translations.
Examining An's record,
from the Essentials of the Way to the Elder of the Four Clans,
there are a total of ninety-two sÅ«tras.
They are marked as ancient and unusual.
Although many of the sÅ«tra texts are scattered and lost,
one can discern the ancient and modern based on the remaining chapters.
Some have no separate titles,
taking the words of the sÅ«tra as the name.
Some are brief summaries of the four Ä€gamas,
extracting a single matter to establish the name and number of the chapter. It is truly an ancient classic.
An Shigao saw their ancient and unusual nature and placed them at the end.
You, based on their distant age, placed them at the beginning.
Although they are lost sources, the old translations can still be seen.

Newly Compiled Record of Lost Translations by Master An, Part 2. Master An's old record was collated by You.
The sutras with translated names were recorded in the upper fascicle.
Those without translated names were listed in the lower section.
Recorded by Dao'an.ğŸ”½From the Sutra on the Practice and Past Lives of the Buddha up to the Sutra on the Buddha's Past Life as a Horse.
A total of 134 sutras.
The author is unknown.
The catalogs of the states of Guan and Liang both omit the translator's name.
Now they are listed in order, included in the section on lost sources.
Dao'an's catalog is truly excellent.
But it is regrettable that it is too concise.
Looking at the sutra titles, I select two characters.
And do not list the number of scrolls, the lines are connected.
Later people transmit and copy, the names and sections are mixed.
Moreover, I use vermilion dots as markers.
When the vermilion is erased, it becomes chaotic.
Following the void, searching is difficult to understand.
This is also a flaw in the jade.
Moreover, the various catalogs mix sutras, anthologies, and miscellaneous works, the titles are often repeated, lost, scattered, and disordered.
Now I have completely revised and corrected them, marking and determining the scrolls and sections, so that the names and reality have a division, and the perusal is without confusion.

the one fascicle of the Method of Beating the GandÄ«. From the Sutra of Balgasa to the Method of Beating the GandÄ«, there are a total of ten
works. They were previously in the monk An's catalog of annotated sutras, but their origins were not sought. Either they were obtained later or they were collected late.

all are lost. This sutra has a total of one hundred and forty-two works.
